column1: Brookings is a city in Brookings County
column3: United States. Brookings is the fourth largest city in South Dakota
column5: 056 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Brookings County
column6: and home to South Dakota State University
column7: the largest institution of higher education in the state. Also found in Brookings are the South Dakota Art Museum

column10: and the headquarters of a number of manufacturing companies and agricultural operations.

column1: The county and city were both named after one of South Dakota's pioneer promoters
column2: Wilmot Brookings (1830 - 1905). Brookings set out for the Dakota Territory in June 1857. He arrived at Sioux Falls on August 27
column4: and became one of the first settlers there. He and his group represented the Western Town Company. After a time in Sioux Falls
column5: Brookings and a companion set out for the Yankton area to locate a town in an area that was soon to be ceded by the Native Americans. This trip was begun in January 1858
column6: and the two soon encountered a blizzard that froze Brookings' feet which both had to be amputated.

column1: He rose to a high position in the Territory
column2: once being a member of the Squatter Territorial Legislature and later being elected Squatter Governor. Brookings then became appointed superintendent of a road that was to be built from the Minnesota state line west to the Missouri River about 30 miles north of Ft. Pierre. It was during the construction of this road that Brookings came into contact with land that was part of this county at the time. Because of his drive to settle the Dakota Territory
column3: Brookings County and city were named for a spirited pioneer promoter. Wilmot W. Brookings made settlement of this area a real possibility for many people.

column1: The first real town that was organized in Brookings County was Medary in 1857. Up to this point
column2: the area had been traveled and utilized by only Native Americans
column3: with a few indistinct traces left showing the penetration of the area by explorers
column6: and traders. Along with Sioux Falls and Flandreau
column7: Medary was one of the first three European settlements to be established in South Dakota.

column1: The first actual site of Medary was located by the Dakota Land Company out of Minnesota which was led by Alpheus G. Fuller and Major Franklin J. DeWitt and accompanied by engineer Samuel A. Medary
column3: the men put up quarters in preparation to live out the winter in Medary. Many other settlers moved into the area in 1858. But in the spring of that year
column4: a large group of Yankton and Yanktonnia Indians drove the settlers from the area
column5: and Medary remained nearly abandoned for the next 11 years.

column2: a group of 10 Norwegian pioneers moved west into the Dakota Territory and resettled the area of Medary
column3: which was located about four and one half miles south of present-day Brookings. The county of Brookings was formally organized in Medary in the cabin of Martin Trygstad on July 3
column4: 1871. The original boundaries of the county extended to two miles south of Flandreau
column5: until the territorial legislature relocated the boundaries of the county to the current location on January 8
column8: appeared in the Brookings County area around this time. All three settlements hoped that they would be the lucky town by which the railroad would decide to lay tracks through as it moved westward but it didn't go through Medary so it became a ghost town.

column2: none of the three towns were chosen to be passed through by the railroad. When the businessmen of Medary and Fountain found out that the railroad had no plans of laying tracks through the two towns
column3: they began a push to find a central location. In a sense
column4: their attitude was 'if you can't beat 'em
column5: join 'em!' Many private meetings and much effort on the part of the men of Medary and Fountain led to the railroad deciding to lay its tracks through what would become the city of Brookings.

column1: In a letter sent to Chicago on September 30
column3: Land Commissioner Charles E. Simmons communicated the layout of the series of towns in Brookings County to be passed through by the railroad. These towns were to be Aurora
column5: and Volga. Many merchants of Medary and Fountain packed up their businesses and belongings and moved to Brookings
column6: which was surveyed and platted on October 3 and 4
column7: 1879. Fountain ceased to exist after this turn of events
column8: while Medary and Oakwood continued to exist for a while but eventually faded away. A monument still stands at the site of the old Medary as a reminder of the people who once lived there.

column1: The railroad crossed the Minnesota state line and into Brookings County on October 2
column2: 1879. With tracks being built at about one mile per day
column3: the track and first train reached Brookings' Main Street on October 18
column4: 1879. The railroad station was opened a month later.

column5: and is located in USDA Hardiness Zones 4. The monthly daily average temperature ranges from 12.9 °F (−10.6 °C) in January to 70.3 °F (21.3 °C) in July
column6: while there are nine days of 90 °F (32 °C)+ highs and 36 days with sub-0 °F (−18 °C) lows annually. Snowfall occurs mostly in light to moderate amounts during the winter
